HIS 103.description: Individual research resulting in a research paper on a specific topic in one of various fields of history. May be taught abroad.

HIS 104C.title: Honors Thesis
HIS 104C.description: Completion of a senior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.

HIS 110.title: Themes in World History
HIS 110.description: Topics will emphasize the interaction of diverse regions of the world as well as common patterns of historical change.

HIS 113.title: History of Modern Israel
HIS 113.description: Topics include the rise and fall of utopian Zionism, the century-long struggle between Jews and Arabs, the development of modern Hebrew culture, the conflict between religious and secular Jews, and the nature of Israel's multicultural society.

HIS 126Y.title: The History of Human Rights in Europe
HIS 126Y.description: History of the origins, development, and state of international humanitarian law (IHL) and international human rights law (IHRL) in Europe. Emphasis on Enlightenment-era and modern theories of the source, utility, and limits of human rights.

HIS 145.title: War & Revolution in Europe: 1789-1918
HIS 145.description: Survey of revolutionary movements, international crises, and wars in Europe from the French Revolution to World War I.

HIS 146B.title: Europe in the 20th Century
HIS 146B.description: Survey of the history of Europe since 1939.

HIS 147B.title: European Intellectual History: 1870-1920
HIS 147B.description: Cultural and intellectual watershed of the late-19th and early-20th centuries. Emergence of modern art and literature; psychoanalysis and the new social sciences. Focus on the work of Baudelaire, Wagner, Nietzsche, Freud, Weber and Kafka.

HIS 165.title: Latin American Social Revolutions
HIS 165.description: Major social upheavals since 1900 in selected Latin American nations; similarities and differences in cause, course, and consequence. May be taught abroad.

HIS 168.title: History of Inter-American Relations
HIS 168.description: Diplomatic history of Latin America since independence, intra-Latin American relations, relations with the United States, participation in international organizations, and communism in Latin America.

HIS 178.title: Water in the West: Environment & Politics in America's Arid Lands
HIS 178.description: Politics and environmental consequences of water development in the arid western United States since 1848, with emphasis on California and western rivers, including the Colorado, Columbia, Missouri, and Mississippi. Irrigated settlement, the making of state and federal water law and bureaucracy, urban vs. rural competition, Native water rights, growth of irrigation technologies, groundwater overdraft, wildlife impacts. One half-day field trip required.

HIS 179.title: Asian American History, 1850-Present
HIS 179.description: Historical experience of people of Asian ancestry in the United States from the mid-19th century to the present. Migration, labor, community formation, race relations, women and gender, popular culture.

HIS 192.title: Internship in History
HIS 192.description: Supervised internship and study as historian, archivist, curator, or in another history-related capacity, in an approved organization or institution.

HIS 193B.title: History of the Modern Middle East, From 1914
HIS 193B.description: Middle East from the turn of the 20th century to the present. Themes include the legacy of imperialism, cultural renaissance, the World Wars, nationalism, Palestine/Israel, Islamic revival, gender, revolutionary movements, politics of oil and war, cultural modernism,exile and diaspora.

HIS 195C.title: A History of Vietnam
HIS 195C.description: Overview of Vietnamese history: early state formation in Southeast Asia; expansion/contention in the 17th and 18th centuries; colonial period; war with the US; and post-war developments (with an emphasis on relations with China and the US).

HIS 196B.title: Modern India
HIS 196B.description: Survey of cultural, social, economic, and political aspects of South Asian history from arrival of the British in the 18th century to formation of new independent states-India, Bangladesh, and Pakistan in the 20th century.

HIS 197T.title: Tutoring in History
HIS 197T.description: Tutoring of students in lower division courses. Weekly meeting with instructors in charge of courses. Written reports on methods and materials required. No final examination.

HIS 198.title: Directed Group Study
HIS 198.description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

HIS 201W.title: Sources & General Literature of History: Advanced Topics in World History
HIS 201W.description: Designed primarily for students preparing for higher degrees in history. Advanced Topics in World History.

HIS 201X.title: Sources & General Literature of History: World History
HIS 201X.description: Designed primarily for students preparing for higher degrees in history. (X) World History.

HIS 202C.title: Major Issues in Historical Interpretation: Modern Europe
HIS 202C.description: Fundamental issues and debates in the study of history. Modern Europe. Readings, papers, and class reports.

HIS 202D.title: Major Issues in Historical Interpretation: India
HIS 202D.description: Fundamental issues and debates in the study of history. India. Readings, papers, and class reports.

HIS 202H.title: Major Issues in Historical Interpretation: United States
HIS 202H.description: Fundamental issues and debates in the study of history. United States. Readings, papers, and class reports.

HIS 203C.title: Research Seminar
HIS 203C.description: Designed for students preparing for higher degrees in History. Individual research and analysis resulting in substantial research paper of publishable quality. Completion required of all Ph.D. candidates. The three courses must be taken in continuous sequence, ordinarily during second year.

HIS 389.title: Introductory Seminar for Teaching Assistants
HIS 389.description: An introduction to the broad comparative and theoretical issues of teaching methods and techniques in history.

HIS 390.title: Teaching History in College
HIS 390.description: Designed for teaching assistants with emphasis on problems and procedures encountered by teachers of lower division classes at the university.

HMR 134.title: Human Rights
HMR 134.description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of the origins, evolution, denial and protection of Human Rights.

HMR 138.title: Human Rights, Gender, & Sexuality
HMR 138.description: Gender and sexuality in the context of human rights. Topics include women's participation in the public sphere, the right to change gender, the right for family privacy, and the right to marriage.

HMR 162Y.title: The History of Human Rights in Europe
HMR 162Y.description: History of the origins, development, and state of international humanitarian law (IHL) and international human rights law (IHRL) in Europe. Emphasis on Enlightenment-era and modern theories of the source, utility, and limits of human rights.

HMR 190.title: Seminar
HMR 190.description: Emphasis on current scholarly debate about the methods for analyzing and comparing diverse human rights issues with the intention of integrating disciplined study of the field.

HMR 299.title: Individual Study
HMR 299.description: Individual study for the designated emphasis in human rights.

HNR 090X.title: Honors Discussion Section
HNR 090X.description: Examination of special topics in selected lower division courses through additional readings, discussions, term papers, collaborative work, or special activities, including projects, field and laboratory experiences, computer simulations, creative works.

HNR 092.title: Internship
HNR 092.description: Supervised work experience under the auspices of the Davis Honors Challenge.

HNR 190X.title: Honors Contract
HNR 190X.description: In-depth examination of material in an upper division course as defined in an Honors Contract Proposal submitted by the student. Contract must be approved by the instructor and the Honors Council of the Academic Senate.

HNR 192.title: Internship
HNR 192.description: Supervised work experience under the auspices of the Davis Honors Challenge.

HNR 195.title: Honors Thesis/Honors Project
HNR 195.description: Guided independent study of a selected topic leading to the presentation of an honors thesis/honors project.

HON 298.title: Topics in Hematology
HON 298.description:
Basic concepts of the physiology of the hematopoietic organ, the pathophysiology of hematopoietic disease, and concepts of therapeutics
will be offered for study. The specific topics to be dictated by the interest and background of the students.

HON 299.title: Research
HON 299.description:
Laboratory investigation contributing to the dissertation for a graduate
degree.

HON 460.title: Hematology-Oncology Consult Clerkship
HON 460.description: Acting intern on inpatient hematology/oncology ward service.

HON 461.title: Hematology-Oncology Consult Clerkship
HON 461.description: Student is an integral member of the inpatient hematology and oncology consult service, the bone marrow service, and will attend all conferences sponsored by the Division.

HON 462.title: Hematology-Oncology Ambulatory Clerkship
HON 462.description: Outpatient rotations in related clinics. Participation with members of the subspecialty service in the initial clinical evaluation, work-up, management and follow-up of the patient with hematologic or oncologic disorders.

HPH 192.title: Internship in Human Physiology
HPH 192.description: Supervised work experience in physiology and related fields.

HPH 198.title: Directed Group Study
HPH 198.description: Directed reading, discussion and/or laboratory experience on selected topics.

HPH 298.title: Group Study
HPH 298.description:
For graduate students desiring to explore particular topics in depth.
Lectures and conferences may be involved.

HPH 403.title: Medical Neuroanatomy
HPH 403.description: Anatomy of the normal human nervous system, to include gross external and internal morphology of brain and spinal cord, and function neuroanatomy of motor, sensory and cognitive systems. Incorporates application of neuroanatomy to clinical problem solving.

HPH 498.title: Directed Reading & Group Study
HPH 498.description: Directed reading and discussion on selected topics in human physiology.

HRT 200B.title: Horticulture & Agronomy: Practices
HRT 200B.description: Introduction to horticultural and agronomic cropping systems.  Covers current applied research within agroecology, crop improvement, crop production, postharvest biology.

HUM 002A.title: Global Humanities Forum
HUM 002A.description: Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major figures, works, and genres in world arts and literatures, with emphasis on relationships between history, society, and culture.

HUM 002B.title: American Humanities Forum
HUM 002B.description: Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major figures, works, and genres in American arts and literatures, with emphasis on relationships between history, society, and culture.

HUM 092.title: Internship
HUM 092.description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills.

HUM 192.title: Internship
HUM 192.description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills.

HUM 198.title: Directed Group Study
HUM 198.description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

HUM 292.title: Graduate Internship
HUM 292.description: Individually designed supervised internship, off campus, in community or institutional setting.  Developed with advice of faculty mentor.

HUM 299.title: Individual Research
HUM 299.description: Individual research in the humanities resulting in a formal written research report.

HYD 010.title: Water, Power, Society
HYD 010.description: Water resources issues. How water has been used to gain and wield socio-political power. Water resources development in California as related to current and future sustainability of water quantity and quality. Roles of science and policy in solving water problems.

HYD 092.title: Hydrologic Science Internship
HYD 092.description: Work experience off and on campus in Hydrologic Science. Internship supervised by a member of the faculty.

HYD 118.title: Evapotranspiration Principles, Measurement & Modeling
HYD 118.description: Estimation of evapotranspiration (ET) for irrigation management and water resources planning; including the basic principles and key factors controlling evaporation and ET rates, methods of measuring these factors in the field and remotely, and determination of likely water requirements for crops and various landscape conditions as needed for water resources planning.

HYD 124.title: Plant-Water-Soil Relationships
HYD 124.description: Principles of plant interactions with soil and atmospheric water environments and practical applications to crop management (e.g., irrigation) and plant eco-physiology (e.g., drought).

HYD 243.title: Water Resource Planning & Management
HYD 243.description: Applications of deterministic and stochastic mathematical programming techniques to water resource planning, analysis, design and management. Water allocation, capacity expansion, and reservoir operation. Conjunctive use of surface water and groundwater. Water quality management. Irrigation planning and operation models.

HYD 286.title: Selected Topics in Environmental Remote Sensing
HYD 286.description: In depth investigation of advanced topics in remote sensing applications, measurements, and theory.

IAD 092.title: Internship
IAD 092.description: Supervised internship, off and on campus, in community and institutional settings.

IAD 103.title: Social Change & Agricultural Development
IAD 103.description: How social and cultural factors influence technological change in agriculture; theories of diffusion of innovations; social impact analysis and technology assessment.

IAD 192.title: Internship
IAD 192.description: Supervised internship, off and on campus, in community and institutional settings.

IAD 290.title: Seminar in International Agricultural Development
IAD 290.description: Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics and issues in international agricultural development.

IAD 291.title: Topics in International Agricultural Development
IAD 291.description: Selected topics dealing with current issues in agricultural development in lesser developed nations. Variable content.

IAD 292.title: Graduate Internship
IAD 292.description: Individually designed supervised internship, off or on campus, in community, business or institutional setting. Developed with advice of faculty mentor and Humphrey Coordinator.

IDI 192.title: Research Internship in Internal Medicine
IDI 192.description: Supervised work experience in the division of Infectious Diseases. Undergraduates will have an opportunity to acquire research experience in clinical settings.

IDI 199.title: Infectious Diseases Research
IDI 199.description: Discrete problem requiring reading and actual manual effort in solution will be assigned to each student. Progress and results will be reviewed at intervals with instructor and via seminar presentation.

IDI 299.title: Research in Infectious Diseases
IDI 299.description:
Laboratory investigation contributing to the dissertation for a graduate
degree.

IDI 440.title: Introduction to AIDS & Related Disorders
IDI 440.description: Familiarizes students with the diagnosis and treatment of individuals infected with the human immunodeficiency virus. Interview patients, observe patient care and participate in ongoing clinic research as well as examine alternative lifestyles.

IDI 450.title: Clinical & Social Care of the Injection Drug User
IDI 450.description: Lecture and guided clinical practice in a supervised clinical setting, focusing on the social and medical aspects of health care for injection drug users.

IDI 460.title: Infectious Diseases Clinical Clerkship
IDI 460.description: Patients ill with infectious diseases, including AIDS, will be evaluated and presented at rounds and case conferences. Patients are also seen in the Infectious Diseases Clinic. Instruction in clinical microbiology and the proper use of the laboratory will be provided.

IDI 499.title: Research Topics in Infectious Disease
IDI 499.description:
Discrete problem requiring reading and actual manual effort in solution will be assigned to each student. Progress and results to be reviewed at
intervals with instructor and via seminar presentation.

IMD 092.title: Internship
IMD 092.description: Supervised internship in internal medicine and related fields.

IMD 098.title: Directed Group Study
IMD 098.description: Directed group study in medicine and related fields.

IMD 099.title: Undergraduate Research in Medicine: Molecular & Cell Biology
IMD 099.description: Undergraduate research in medicine, focusing on molecular & cellular biology.

IMD 192.title: Internship in Internal Medicine
IMD 192.description: Supervised work experience in internal medicine and related fields.

IMD 194.title: Practicum in Community Health Clinics
IMD 194.description: The undergraduate student, through active participation in the medical aspects of community health clinics, gains knowledge of the organization, administration, and problem-solving capabilities of these primary care facilities.

IMD 198.title: Directed Group Study
IMD 198.description: Directed group study in medicine and related fields.

IMD 250.title: Medicine & the Law
IMD 250.description: Legal and bioethical principles and concepts in medicine. Topics include standard of care, informed consent, reproductive medicine, and end-of-life issues.

IMD 420A.title: Hematology
IMD 420A.description: Malignant disorders of blood cells and transfusion therapy. Covers acute leukemia, myelodysplasia, myeloproliferative disorders, lymphoma, and myeloma.

IMD 420B.title: Gastrointestinal System
IMD 420B.description: Basic pathophysiologic principles of digestive diseases on which clinical concepts and judgments can be developed. Emphasis on pathophysiologic basis of gastroenterological and hepatic disorders with discussion of major disorders and their diagnosis and management.

IMD 420D.title: Cardiovascular System
IMD 420D.description: Principles of etiology, mechanisms, diagnosis and management of the major diseases of the cardiovascular system. Included are ischemic, valvular, hypertensive, cardiomyopathic, pericardial, and electrical disorders.

IMD 430.title: Medicine Clerkship
IMD 430.description: Clerkship is divided into two, four-week blocks, one each at UCDMC and at Kaiser Hospitals. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.

IMD 462.title: Medicine Wards AI
IMD 462.description: Assume role of acting intern and be primary physician on medical ward under direction of medical resident and staff. Teams I-V take call every fifth night. Emphasis on evidence-based inpatient care.

IMD 463.title: Acting Internship in Medicine Intensive Care Unit (MICU)
IMD 463.description: At UCDMC, student functions as acting intern on MICU service under direction of medical resident and staff. Responsibility for patients admitted to MICU. On call in hospital every fourth night.

IMD 465.title: Medicos-Global Health Sciences
IMD 465.description: Travel to foreign country for four weeks to collaborate with faculty from local universities and work in urban and rural environments, including hands-on experience with clinic patients. Cultural exchange and awareness of global health care.

IMD 469.title: Acting Internship in Medicine Intensive Care Unit (MICU)
IMD 469.description: At UCDMC, student functions as acting intern on MICU service under direction of medical resident and staff. Responsibility for patients admitted to MICU.

IMD 470.title: Critical Evaluation of Landmark Studies in Evidence-Based Medicine
IMD 470.description: Primary objective is to prepare future physicians to effectively integrate evidence-based medicine into their clinical practice. While this course has an Internal Medicine emphasis, the skills the course aims to impartformulating focused clinical questions, searching the medical literature, evaluating the quality of research, and integrating evidence into clinical practice, giving effective article presentations)apply to all future clinicians, regardless of their specialty.

IMD 494.title: Practicum in Community Health Clinics
IMD 494.description: Assigned to clinical settings that demonstrate ethnic, urban/rural, or other related aspects of clinical community health. Through active participation in health care delivery, learn to relate conceptual with practical aspects of primary health care.

IMD 498.title: Group Study in Internal Medicine
IMD 498.description: Special study for medical students which may involve laboratory or library research, ambulatory or inpatient care responsibility on campus, at UCDMC or off campus by specific arrangement.

IMM 297.title: Mucosal Immunology
IMM 297.description: Basic concepts and current research topics in the field of mucosal immunology, with an emphasis on human immunology. Major emphases include innate and adaptive mucosal immunity, the gastrointestinal tract, the lung, lymphocyte trafficking, and mucosal vaccination.

IRE 192.title: International Relations Internship
IRE 192.description: Work experience in international relations, with term paper summarizing the practical experience of the student.

IST 194HB.title: Special Study for Honors Students
IST 194HB.description: A program of research culminating in the writing of a junior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.

IST 197T.title: Tutoring in Integrated Studies
IST 197T.description: Tutoring in Integrated Studies  courses, usually in small discussion groups. Weekly discussions with the instructor on the subject matter of the course being tutored and on the art and craft of teaching.

ITA 003.title: Elementary Italian
ITA 003.description: Continuation of ITA 002 or ITA 002S. Review of grammar and vocabulary, and practice of all language skills through cultural texts.

ITA 023.title: Intermediate Italian
ITA 023.description: Continued development of grammatical structures and vocabulary. Emphasis on reading and writing in Italian.

ITA 032.title: Beginning Italian for Spanish Speakers
ITA 032.description: Continuation of ITA 031. Intensive introductory course to Italian language and grammar with emphasis on oral and written communication. Highlights the structural similarities between Italian and Spanish.

ITA 098.title: Directed Group Study
ITA 098.description: Primarily intended for lower division students.

ITA 105.title: Introduction to Italian Literature
ITA 105.description: Introduction to the study of the principal authors, works, and movements of the Medieval, Renaissance, and Early Modern periods in Italy.

ITA 113.title: Dante Alighieri, Divina Commedia (Inferno, Purgatorio, Paradiso)
ITA 113.description: Study of Dante Alighieri's Divina Commedia, and its role in the development of Italian language and literature. Emphasis will be placed on reading the whole poem within the historical context of the Middle Ages.

ITA 192.title: Italian Internship
ITA 192.description:
Participation in government and business activities to gain work experience and to develop a better knowledge of Italian language and
culture.

ITA 194H.title: Special Study for Honors Students
ITA 194H.description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member, leading to a senior honors thesis on a topic in Italian literature, civilization, or language studies.

ITA 195H.title: Honors Thesis
ITA 195H.description: Writing of an honors thesis on a topic in Italian literature, civilization, or language studies under the direction of a faculty member.

ITA 197T.title: Tutoring in Italian
ITA 197T.description: Tutoring in undergraduate courses, including leadership in small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with departmental courses.

ITA 197TC.title: Community Tutoring in Italian
ITA 197TC.description: Field experience as Italian tutors or teacher's aides.

ITA 198.title: Directed Group Study
ITA 198.description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

JPN 003.title: Elementary Japanese
JPN 003.description: Continuation of training in basic spoken and written skills in Japanese language. May be taught abroad.

JPN 006.title: Intermediate Japanese
JPN 006.description: Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Japanese in cultural context, based on language skills developed in JPN 005. May be taught abroad.

JPN 103.title: Japanese Literature in Translation: The Modern Period
JPN 103.description: Modern Japanese literature from the late 19th century to the present with focus on the concept of modernity; in addition to the study of authors and genres, examines historical and cultural contexts. Lectures, readings and discussions in English.

JPN 106.title: Japanese Culture Through Film
JPN 106.description: Aspects of Japanese culture such as love, sexuality, war, the military, the family, the position of women, growing up and death as portrayed in Japanese cinema. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Films with English subtitles.

JPN 113.title: Modern Japanese: Reading & Discussion
JPN 113.description: Continuation of JPN 112. May be taught abroad.

JPN 152.title: Traditional Japanese Drama
JPN 152.description: Survey in English of Japanese drama, focusing on traditional forms: noh, kygen, bunraku puppet theater, and kabuki, with some attention to modern theater. Texts of plays and secondary works on performance techniques and the composition of plays.

JPN 158.title: The Supernatural in Japan
JPN 158.description: Depictions of the supernatural in Japanese history through the contemporary era. Overview of Japanese literary and visual arts and the socio-historical contexts of the supernatural. Lectures and readings in English. Films in Japanese with English subtitles.

JPN 165.title: Sexuality & Love in Premodern Japanese Literature
JPN 165.description: Love and eros in opposite-sex, same-sex, marital, premarital, extramarital, commercial and amateur modes and in aristocratic, samurai and commoner milieus as reflected in works of literature produced in Japan between the 700s and 1867. Readings, lectures and discussions in English.

JPN 192.title: Japanese Internship
JPN 192.description: Work experience in Japanese language, with analytical term paper on a topic approved by instructor.

JPN 194H.title: Special Thesis Honors Project
JPN 194H.description: Guided research, under the direction of a senate faculty member, leading to a senior thesis project on a topic in Japanese literature, culture, linguistics, or language studies.

JPN 197T.title: Tutoring in Japanese
JPN 197T.description: Leading of small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with one of the Program's regular courses.

LAT 003.title: Intermediate Latin
LAT 003.description: Continuation of LAT 002. Selected readings from Latin authors.

LAT 125.title: Medieval Latin
LAT 125.description: Selected readings from the Vulgate and various medieval authors provide an introduction to the developments in the Latin Language and literature from the 4th to the 15th centuries.

LDA 003.title: Sustainable Development: Theory & Practice
LDA 003.description:
Origins, theoretical perspectives, and practical applications of the concept of sustainable development across scales (site,
building, neighborhood, city, region, and nation) through lectures, sketch exercises, student projects, walking tours.

LDA 010.title: World Regional Geography
LDA 010.description: Major geographic regions of the world; physical and human geography of each region; interactions between the people and the environment; culture and landscape; major resources; physical environments; population distribution and major cities.

LDA 023.title: Landscape Representation II
LDA 023.description: Methods to explore and communicate environmental design intentions through digital media.

LDA 050.title: Site Ecology
LDA 050.description: Introduction to ecological concepts, including nutrient dynamics, population regulation, community structure, ecosystem function. Principles will be applied to human activities such as biological conservation, ecological restoration, landscape planning, and management. Weekly lab devoted to field exercises in local ecosystems.

LDA 060.title: Landform & Grading Studio
LDA 060.description: Introduction of landform and topography as landscape medium and utilization of grading and drainage to design meaningful and functional spaces. Intro to site analysis and site planning, with specific attention to topography.

LDA 098.title: Directed Group Study in Landscape Architecture

LDA 142.title: Applying Sustainable Strategies
LDA 142.description: Capstone class examines case studies and techniques of sustainable development. Student teams will develop detailed proposals for real-world sites.

LDA 150.title: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
LDA 150.description: Basic concepts, principles, and methods of GIS are presented. Data structures, database design, GIS data creation, GPS, and spatial analysis. May be taught abroad.

LDA 171.title: Urban Design & Planning Studio
LDA 171.description: Studio designing large-scale landscapes at regional, sub-regional, and neighborhood scales. Focuses on understanding complex social, economic, and environmental factors, developing sustainability priorities and strategies, and applying them through design and policy.

LDA 184.title: Capstone Landscape Architecture Studio
LDA 184.description: Capstone studio that synthesizes learning objectives within the senior-level Landscape Architecture studio sequence. Students required to apply creative problem solving, design theory, technology, and representation skills towards a design approach that addresses complex, real-world environmental design problems.

LDA 190.title: Proseminar in Landscape Architecture
LDA 190.description: Lectures and discussion of critical issues in landscape architecture.

LDA 192.title: Internship in Landscape Architecture
LDA 192.description: Professional field experience in landscape architecture.

LDA 198.title: Directed Group Study in Landscape Architecture
LDA 198.description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

LDA 199.title: Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates in Landscape Architecture

LDA 215.title: What is Infrastructure: Critical Infrastructure Studies
LDA 215.description: Introduction to interdisciplinary scholarship and design on expanding conceptions of infrastructure, that include social, technical, ecological, political and aesthetic dimensions of the medium.  Focus on application of theory to case studies and thinking through landscape as infrastructure.

LDA 299.title: Directed Individual Research for Graduate Students

LIN 001.title: Introduction to Linguistics
LIN 001.description: Introduction to the study of language; its nature, diversity, and structure.

LIN 001Y.title: Introduction to Linguistics
LIN 001Y.description: Introduction to the study of language; its nature, diversity, and structure.

LIN 003.title: Language & the Body
LIN 003.description: Perspectives on the role of language in issues about bodies. Language-related disabilities. Social implications of language use in discussing body-related conditions.

LIN 096.title: Directed Group Study in English as a Second Language
LIN 096.description: Directed group study of topic in English as a Second Language (ESL).

LIN 112.title: Phonetics
LIN 112.description: Detailed examination of articulatory and acoustic phonetics.

LIN 131.title: Introduction to Syntactic Theory
LIN 131.description: Introduction to syntactic theory, primarily through the examination of a major theory of syntax, emphasizing theoretical reasoning, argumentation, and problems of theory building in syntax.

LIN 165.title: Introduction to Applied Linguistics
LIN 165.description: Applications of linguistic principles and the analysis of language-related issues in the world.  Exploration of a range of language-related problems including issues related to language learning and teaching to issues concerning language and gender, race, class and the media.

LIN 177.title: Computational Linguistics
LIN 177.description: Understanding the nature of language through computer modeling of linguistic abilities.  Relationships between human cognition and computer representations of cognitive processing.

LIN 182.title: Multilingualism
LIN 182.description: Issues in multilingualism from a global perspective: e.g., multilingual communities; multilingualism and identity (gender, ethnicity, nationality); language ideologies and educational and sociopolitical policies surrounding multilingualism; acquisition of multilingualism; discursive practices of multilinguals.

LIN 192.title: Internship in Linguistics
LIN 192.description: Internship applying linguistic-related skills to a fieldwork project in areas such as media, law, or industry, in approved organizations or institutions. Maximum of 4 units applicable toward major.

LIN 194H.title: Special Study for Honors Students
LIN 194H.description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member approved by the Program Director, leading to a senior honors thesis.

LIN 197T.title: Tutoring in Linguistics
LIN 197T.description: Leading of small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with one of the department's regular courses.

LIN 201.title: Proseminar
LIN 201.description: Introduction to research activity of faculty in the Graduate Group in Linguistics and guest speakers.

LIN 205C.title: Topics in Linguistic Theory & Methods
LIN 205C.description: Advanced study of current problems in linguistic theory and methodology.

LIN 241.title: Advanced Syntactic Theory & Analysis
LIN 241.description: Advanced critical exploration of contemporary theories of linguistic semantics.

LIN 250.title: Principles of Typological Linguistics
LIN 250.description: Cross-linguistic comparison and typology, including word order, morphological typology, complex clauses, semantic categories and their grammaticalization, and applications of typology to language acquisition.

LIN 297T.title: English as a Second Language Teaching/Tutoring
LIN 297T.description: Teaching classes for ESL graduate students. Aiding the ESL undergraduate composition classes; tutoring foreign graduate student Teaching Assistants in pronunciation. Does not fulfill requirement toward the M.A. degree.

MAE 207.title: Engineering Experimentation & Uncertainty Analysis
MAE 207.description: Design and analysis of engineering experiments with emphasis on measurement standards, data analysis, regressions and general and detailed uncertainty analysis, including statistical treatment of experimental data intervals, propagation of bias and precision errors, correlated bias approximations, and using jitter programs.

MAE 245.title: Micro- & Nano-Technology in Life Sciences
MAE 245.description: Survey of biodevice design from engineering and biological perspectives; micro-/nano-fabrication techniques; surface science and mass transport; essential biological processes and models; proposal development skills on merging aforementioned themes.

MAE 253.title: Network Theory & Applications
MAE 253.description: Develops the mathematical theory underlying growth, structure and function of networks with applications to physical, social, biological and engineered systems. Topics include network growth, resilience, epidemiology, phase transitions, software and algorithms, routing and search control, cascading failures.

MAE 258.title: Hybrid Electric Vehicle System Theory & Design
MAE 258.description: Advanced vehicle design for fuel economy, performance, and low emissions, considering regulations, societal demands and manufacturability. Analysis and verification of computer design and control of vehicle systems in real vehicle tests. Advanced engine concepts.

MAE 265.title: Aeroacoustics
MAE 265.description: Introduction to acoustics, Fourier transform and sound pressure level, Greens function, Lighthills acoustic analogy and jet noise, tailored Greens function and acoustic scattering, Ffowcs Williams and Hawkings equation and rotorcraft noise, turbulence for aeroacoustics and leading-edge noise, trailing-edge noise and wind turbine noise, duct acoustics and aircraft engine noise.

MAE 297.title: SEMINAR
MAE 297.description: Current topics in engineering including developments in mechanical and aeronautical engineering with presentations by students, faculty, and visitors.

MAT 012.title: Precalculus
MAT 012.description: Topics selected for their use in calculus, including functions and their graphs, slope, zeroes of polynomials, exponential, logarithmic and trigonometric functions, sketching surfaces and solids.

MAT 016A.title: Short Calculus
MAT 016A.description: Limits; differentiation of algebraic functions; analytic geometry; applications, in particular to maxima and minima problems.

MAT 016B.title: Short Calculus
MAT 016B.description: Integration; calculus for trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions; applications.

MAT 016C.title: Short Calculus
MAT 016C.description: Differential equations; partial derivatives; double integrals; applications; series.

MAT 017A.title: Calculus for Biology & Medicine
MAT 017A.description: Introduction to differential calculus via applications in biology and medicine. Limits, derivatives of polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential functions, graphing, applications of the derivative to biology and medicine.

MAT 017B.title: Calculus for Biology & Medicine
MAT 017B.description: Introduction to integral calculus and elementary differential equations via applications to biology and medicine. Fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration including integral tables and numerical methods, improper integrals, elementary first order differential equations, applications in biology and medicine.

MAT 017C.title: Calculus for Biology & Medicine
MAT 017C.description: Matrix algebra, functions of several variables, partial derivatives, systems of differential equations, and applications to biology and medicine.

MAT 021A.title: Calculus
MAT 021A.description: Functions, limits, continuity. Slope and derivative. Differentiation of algebraic and transcendental functions. Applications to motion, natural growth, graphing, extrema of a function. Differentials. L'Hopital's rule.

MAT 021B.title: Calculus
MAT 021B.description: Continuation of MAT 021A. Definition of definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration. Application to area, volume, arc length, average of a function, improper integral, surface of revolution. May be taught abroad.

MAT 021C.title: Calculus
MAT 021C.description: Continuation of MAT 021B. Sequences, series, tests for convergence, Taylor expansions. Vector algebra, vector calculus, scalar and vector fields. Partial derivatives, total differentials. Applications to maximum and minimum problems in two or more variables. Applications to physical systems.

MAT 021D.title: Vector Analysis
MAT 021D.description: Continuation of MAT 021C. Definite integrals over plane and solid regions in various coordinate systems. Line and surface integrals. Green's theorem, Stoke's theorem, divergence theorem.

MAT 022A.title: Linear Algebra
MAT 022A.description: Matrices and linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, diagonalization, factorization.

MAT 022AL.title: Linear Algebra Computer Laboratory
MAT 022AL.description: Introduction to MATLAB and its use in linear algebra.

MAT 027B.title: Differential Equations with Applications to Biology
MAT 027B.description: Solutions of differential equations with biological, medical, and bioengineering applications. First and second order linear equations, phase plane analysis, nonlinear dynamics, Laplace transforms, and the diffusion equation. Computer labs cover mathematical and numerical techniques for modeling biological systems.

MAT 107.title: Probability & Stochastic Processes with Applications to Biology
MAT 107.description: Introduction to probability theory and stochastic processes with biological, medical, and bioengineering applications. Combinatorics, discrete and continuous random variables, Bayes formula, conditional probability, Markov chains, Poisson processes, and Brownian motion. Computer labs cover mathematical and computational modeling techniques.

MAT 108.title: Introduction to Abstract Mathematics
MAT 108.description: Rigorous treatment of mathematical concepts with emphasis on developing the ability to understand abstract mathematical ideas, to read and write mathematical concepts, and to prove theorems. Designed to serve as preparation for the more rigorous upper division courses.

MAT 114.title: Convex Geometry
MAT 114.description: Topics selected from the theory of convex bodies, convex functions, geometric inequalities, combinatorial geometry, and integral geometry. Designed to serve as preparation for the more rigorous upper division courses.

MAT 119B.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
MAT 119B.description: Lorentz equations; Poincare maps; center manifolds and normal forms; scalar and planar maps; phase space analysis for iterated maps; period-doubling bifurcation; Lyapunov exponent; chaos and symbolic dynamics; strange attractors; fractals.

MAT 127A.title: Real Analysis
MAT 127A.description: Real numbers, sequences, series, and continuous functions.

MAT 127B.title: Real Analysis
MAT 127B.description: Derivatives, integrals, sequences of functions, and power series.

MAT 128B.title: Numerical Analysis in Solution of Equations
MAT 128B.description: Solution of nonlinear equations and nonlinear systems. Minimization of functions of several variables. Simultaneous linear equations. Eigenvalue problems. Linear programming. Programming in language such as Pascal, Fortran, or BASIC required.

MAT 128C.title: Numerical Analysis in Differential Equations
MAT 128C.description: Difference equations, operators, numerical solutions of ordinary and partial differential equations. Programming in language such as Pascal, Fortran, or BASIC required.

MAT 133.title: Mathematical Finance
MAT 133.description: Analysis and evaluation of deterministic and random cash flow streams, yield and pricing of basic financial instruments, interest rate theory, mean-variance portfolio theory, capital asset pricing models, utility functions and general principles. MATLAB programming required.

MAT 135A.title: Probability
MAT 135A.description: Probability space; discrete probability, combinatorial analysis; independence, conditional probability; random variables, discrete and continuous distributions, probability mass function, joint and marginal density functions; expectation, moments, variance, Chebyshev inequality; sums of random variables, random walk, large number law, central limit theorem.

MAT 135B.title: Stochastic Processes
MAT 135B.description: Generating functions, branching processes, characteristic function; Markov chains; convergence of random variables, law of iterated logarithm; random processes, Brownian motion, stationary processes, renewal processes, queueing theory, martingales.

MAT 141.title: Euclidean Geometry
MAT 141.description: Axiomatic and analytic examination of Euclidean geometry from an advanced point of view.  In particular, a discussion of its relation to other geometries. Designed to serve as preparation for the more rigorous upper division courses.

MAT 145.title: Combinatorics
MAT 145.description: Combinatorial methods using basic graph theory, counting methods, generating functions, and recurrence relations. Designed to serve as preparation for the more rigorous upper division courses.

MAT 146.title: Algebraic Combinatorics
MAT 146.description: Enumeration, Polya theory, generating functions, current topics in algebraic combinatorics.

MAT 167.title: Applied Linear Algebra
MAT 167.description: Applications of linear algebra; LU and QR matrix factorizations, eigenvalue and singular value matrix decompositions.

MAT 170.title: Mathematics for Data Analytics & Decision Making
MAT 170.description: Relational model; relational algebra, relational calculus, normal forms, functional and multivalued dependencies, separability. Cost benefit analysis of physical database design and reorganization. Performance via analytical modeling, simulation, and queueing theory. Block accesses; buffering; operating system contention; CPU intensive operations.

MAT 180.title: Special Topics
MAT 180.description: Special topics from various fields of modern, pure, and applied mathematics.  Some recent topics include Knot Theory, General Relativity, and Fuzzy Sets.

MAT 185A.title: Complex Analysis
MAT 185A.description: Complex number system, analyticity and the Cauchy-Riemann equations, elementary functions, complex integration, power and Laurent series expansions, residue theory.

MAT 189.title: Advanced Problem Solving
MAT 189.description: Solution and presentation of advanced problem solving techniques. Solve and present interesting and challenging problems of all areas of mathematics.

MAT 192.title: Internship in Applied Mathematics
MAT 192.description: Supervised work experience in applied mathematics. Final report.

MAT 194.title: Undergraduate Thesis
MAT 194.description: Independent research under supervision of a faculty member. Student will submit written report in thesis form.

MAT 197TC.title: Tutoring Mathematics in the Community
MAT 197TC.description: Special projects in mathematical education developing techniques for mathematics instruction and tutoring on an individual or small group basis.

MAT 201C.title: Analysis
MAT 201C.description: Metric and normed spaces. Continuous functions. Topological, Hilbert, and Banach spaces. Fourier series. Spectrum of bounded and compact linear operators. Linear differential operators and Green's functions. Distributions. Fourier transform. Measure theory. Lp and Sobolev spaces. Differential calculus and variational methods.

MAT 205B.title: Complex Analysis
MAT 205B.description: Conformal mappings, the Schwarz lemma, analytic automorphisms, the Riemann mapping theorem, elliptic functions, Eisenstein series, the Jacobi theta functions, asymptotics, Bessel functions, the Airy function, topics on special functions and Riemann surfaces.

MAT 206.title: Measure Theory
MAT 206.description: Introduction to measure theory.  The study of lengths, surface areas, and volumes in general spaces, as related to integration theory.

MAT 207C.title: Methods of Applied Mathematics
MAT 207C.description: Ordinary differential equations and dynamical systems. Variational principles. Eigenfunctions, integral equations and Green's functions. Complex analysis and contour integration. Laplace's equation. Diffusion equations. Wave phenomena. Dimensional analysis and scaling. Asymptotic expansions and perturbation theory. Stochastic processes and Brownian motion.

MAT 215B.title: Topology
MAT 215B.description: Fundamental group and covering space theory. Homology and cohomology. Manifolds and duality. CW complexes. Fixed point theorems.

MAT 221A.title: Mathematical Fluid Dynamics
MAT 221A.description: Kinematics and dynamics of fluids. The Euler and Navier-Stokes equations. Vorticity dynamics. Irrotational flow. Low Reynolds number flows and the Stokes equations. High Reynolds number flows and boundary layers. Compressible fluids. Shock waves.

MAT 227.title: Mathematical Biology
MAT 227.description: Nonlinear ordinary and partial differential equations and stochastic processes of cell and molecular biology. Scaling, qualitative, and numerical analysis of mathematical models. Applications to nerve impulse, chemotaxis, muscle contraction, and morphogenesis.

MAT 228C.title: Numerical Solution of Differential Equations
MAT 228C.description: Numerical solutions of initial-value, eigenvalue and boundary-value problems for ordinary differential equations. Numerical solution of parabolic and hyperbolic partial differential equations.

MAT 240B.title: Differential Geometry
MAT 240B.description: Jacobi fields, conjugate points, completeness, Hopf-Rinow theorem, Cartan-Hadamard theorem, energy, variation theorems and their applications, Rauch comparison theorem and its applications.

MAT 250C.title: Algebra
MAT 250C.description: Group and rings. Sylow theorems, abelian groups, Jordan-Holder theorem. Rings, unique factorization. Algebras, and modules. Fields and vector spaces over fields. Field extensions. Commutative rings. Representation theory and its applications.

MAT 258A.title: Numerical Optimization
MAT 258A.description: Numerical methods for infinite dimensional optimization problems.  Newton and Quasi-Newton methods, linear and sequential quadratic programming, barrier methods; large-scale optimization; theory of approximations; infinite and semi-infinite programming; applications to optimal control, stochastic optimization and distributed systems.

MAT 261.title: Lie Groups & Lie Algebras
MAT 261.description: Lie groups, examples and topological properties. Lie algebras and representation theory and semisimple Lie algebras.

MAT 271.title: Applied & Computational Harmonic Analysis
MAT 271.description: Introduction to mathematical basic building blocks (wavelets, local Fourier basis, and their relatives) useful for diverse fields (signal and image processing, numerical analysis, and statistics). Emphasis on the connection between the continuum and the discrete worlds.

MAT 280.title: Topics in Pure & Applied Mathematics
MAT 280.description: Special topics in various fields of pure and applied mathematics. Topics selected based on the mutual interests of students and faculty.

MAT 290.title: Seminar
MAT 290.description: Advanced study in various fields of mathematics, including analysis, applied mathematics, discrete mathematics, geometry, mathematical biology, mathematical physics, optimization, partial differential equations, probability, and topology.

MAT 399.title: Individual Study
MAT 399.description: Individual study of some aspect of mathematics education or a focused work on a curriculum design project under supervision of a faculty member in mathematics.

MCB 010.title: Introduction to Human Heredity
MCB 010.description: Topics in human heredity and human gene structure and function, including the genetic basis of human development, causes of birth defects, mental retardation, genetic diseases, sexual determination, development, and behavior.

MCB 110Y.title: iBioseminars in Cell & Molecular Biology
MCB 110Y.description: Hybrid course in Cellular & Molecular Biology for senior level (1) Biochemistry/Molecular Biology; (2) Genetics; or (3) Cell Biology majors. Face-to-face instruction combined with online lectures available at iBioseminars website delivered by leading researchers in Cellular & Molecular Biology.

MCB 120.title: Molecular Biology & Biochemistry Laboratory Associated Lecture
MCB 120.description: Introduction to laboratory methods and procedures employed in studying molecular biology and biochemical processes. Lecture component for MCB 120L.

MCB 120L.title: Molecular Biology & Biochemistry Laboratory
MCB 120L.description: Introduction to laboratory methods and procedures employed in studying molecular biology and biochemical processes. Designed for students who need experience in use of molecular biology and biochemical techniques as research and analytical tools.

MCB 121.title: Advanced Molecular Biology
MCB 121.description: Structure, expression, and regulation of eukaryotic genes. Chromosome structure and replication; gene structure, transcription, and RNA processing; protein synthesis and translation control; development, immune system, and oncogenes.

MCB 123.title: Behavior & Analysis of Enzyme & Receptor Systems
MCB 123.description: Introduction to the principles of enzyme kinetics and receptor-ligand interactions with emphasis on metabolic regulation and data analysis. Topics include simultaneous equilibria, chemical and steady-state kinetics, allosteric enzymes, mulitreactant systems, enzyme assays, membrane transport and computer-assisted simulations and analyses.

MCB 143.title: Cell & Molecular Biophysics
MCB 143.description: Physical chemical principles by which molecules form living, moving, reproducing cells.  Physical nature of cytoplasm; molecular structure/bonding in macromolecules, macromolecular assemblies and protein machines.  Physical techniques and modeling of cytoskeletal polymer-motor dynamics and function during intracellular transport, mitosis and motility.

MCB 145.title: Assembly & Function of Cell Signaling Machinery
MCB 145.description: Molecular basis of cell signaling, including positioning of cellular machinery, components of various signaling pathways, and downstream effects of signaling on cell adhesion, cell differentiation, and programmed cell death.

MCB 160L.title: Principles of Genetics Laboratory
MCB 160L.description: Laboratory work in basic and molecular genetics including gene mapping, isolation and characterization of mutants in eukaryotic model systems, reverse genetics, gel electrophoresis, recombinant DNA techniques, and PCR.

MCB 182.title: Principles of Genomics
MCB 182.description: Fundamentals of genomics, including structural genomics, functional genomics, proteomics, and bioinformatics,  focusing on the impact of these disciplines on research in the biological sciences. Social impacts of genomic research.

MCB 190C.title: Undergraduate Research Conference
MCB 190C.description: Presentation and discussion of current research by faculty and students.

MCB 192.title: Internship
MCB 192.description: Technical and/or practical experience on and off campus, supervised by a member of the Section of Molecular and Cellular Biology faculty.

MCB 193.title: Advanced Research
MCB 193.description: Research project carried out under the supervision of a faculty sponsor. Discussion and analysis of results and proposed experiments on a weekly basis with faculty sponsor. May include presentation of a seminar to a research group.

MCB 194.title: Thesis Research
MCB 194.description: Continuation of an intensive, individual laboratory research project in biochemistry, genetics, or cell biology culminating with the presentation of the work in a written thesis and in a seminar.

MCB 194H.title: Research Honors
MCB 194H.description: Honors project. Continuation of an intensive, individual laboratory research project in biochemistry, genetics, or cell biology culminating with the presentation of the work in a written thesis and in a seminar.

MCB 197T.title: Tutoring in Molecular & Cellular Biology
MCB 197T.description: Assisting the instructor in one of the section's regular courses by tutoring individual or small groups of students in a laboratory, in voluntary discussion groups, or other voluntary course activities.

MCB 198.title: Directed Group Study
MCB 198.description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

MCB 259.title: Literature in Developmental Biology
MCB 259.description: Critical presentation and analysis of recent journal articles in developmental biology.

MCB 282.title: Biotechnology Internship
MCB 282.description: Research at a biotechnology company or interdisciplinary cross-college lab for a minimum of 3 months as part of the Designated Emphasis in Biotechnology Program.

MCB 290C.title: Research Conference
MCB 290C.description: Presentations and critical discussions of faculty and graduate student research in molecular and cellular biology including biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology.

MCB 291.title: Current Progress in Molecular & Cellular Biology
MCB 291.description: Seminars presented by guest lecturers on subject of their own research activities.

MCB 390.title: Methods of Teaching
MCB 390.description:
Practical experience in the methods and problems of teaching biochemistry/genetics/cell biology. Includes analysis of texts and
supporting material, discussion of teaching techniques, preparing for and conducting discussion and laboratory sections, formulating examinations under supervision of instructor. Participating in the teaching program required for Ph.D.

MCN 263.title: Applied Research Methods in Maternal & Child Nutrition
MCN 263.description: Application of epidemiological principles to the study of maternal and child nutrition. Topics include quantitative & qualitative study procedures, including study design, data collection, and related analytical techniques.

MCN 264B.title: Current Topics in Maternal & Child Nutrition: Epidemiology & Evidence-Based Practice
MCN 264B.description: Current scientific literature related to Maternal & Child Nutrition. Topics include epidemiology, evidence-based practice, breastfeeding promotion, and nutritional assessment of populations.

MCN 264C.title: Current Topics in Maternal & Child Nutrition: Public Policy Development & Implementation
MCN 264C.description: Current scientific literature related to Maternal & Child Nutrition. Topics include nutrition surveillance and monitoring, as well as public policy development and implementation.

MCP 210C.title: Advanced Physiology
MCP 210C.description: Graduate level instruction in the general principles of physiology and the neural and humoral control of the cardiovascular, renal, respiratory, gastrointestinal, sensory, musculoskeletal, and reproductive systems.

MCP 215.title: Electrophysiology Techniques & Applications
MCP 215.description: Broad scope of topics in electrophysiology techniques and applications.

MCP 222.title: Mammalian Gametogenesis & Fertilization
MCP 222.description: Emphasizes our current understanding of events in mammalian gametogenesis and the fertilization process. Published results, conclusions drawn from these results, and their contribution to our understanding are discussed.

MCP 234.title: Current Topics in Neurotoxicology
MCP 234.description: General principles of neurotoxicology, the cell and molecular mechanisms and health impacts of specific neurotoxicants and the contribution of neurotoxic compounds to complex neurodevelopmental disorders and neurodegenerative diseases.

MCP 255.title: Physiology of the Stress Response
MCP 255.description: Definition of Stress; Physiological mechanisms of adaptation to stress; Hormonal control of the systemic stress response; Mechanisms of the cellular stress response; Discussion of current trends in stress physiology and current methods for studying the stress response;

MCP 290.title: Seminar
MCP 290.description: Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics and current trends in research.

MCP 290C.title: Research Conference in Physiology
MCP 290C.description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and graduate student research in physiology.

MCP 390.title: The Teaching of Physiology
MCP 390.description: Practical experience in methods and problems of teaching physiology lecture courses. May include analyses of texts and supporting material, discussion of teaching techniques, preparing for and conducting discussion sessions, and formulation of topics and questions for examinations under supervision of instructor.

MDS 192.title: Medical Education Internship for Advanced Undergraduates
MDS 192.description:
Participate in projects related to curriculum development in support of curriculum for M.D. degree. Gain work experience and appreciation
for innovative approaches to learning in basic and clinical sciences of medical education.

MDS 412.title: ACE-PC Clinical Skills Foundation
MDS 412.description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social and clinical science to clinical cases in small groups. History, physical examination with preceptors. Didactics in epidemiology, ethics, sexuality and clinical reasoning. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of medicine. Includes small case-based learning groups with training in patient communication and interviewing techniques.

MDS 430.title: Introduction to Doctoring 3
MDS 430.description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social and clinical science concepts to clinical cases in small group discussions facilitated by medical school faculty. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of clinical medicine.

MDS 440.title: Doctoring 4 Teaching Fellowship
MDS 440.description: Instruction on teaching methodology and pedagogy. Mentored teaching of junior medical students in seminar, lecture, and bedside.

MDS 468C.title: International Clinical Preceptorship
MDS 468C.description: Multidisciplinary preceptorship in a foreign country. Clinical credit will be awarded using this course, once approval has been received from the appropriate governing committee.

MDS 478.title: I-RESTORE (Pre-Clerkship Intersession)
MDS 478.description: Presents additional integration of the biomedical, clinical and health systems sciences, support for professional identity formation and wellness. Held longitudinally throughout the pre-clerkship phase.

MDS 479.title: Clerkship Intersession Course
MDS 479.description: Longitudinal experience to supplement and support the clerkships in their efforts to facilitate students acquisition of the graduation competencies; to ensure biomedical science and health systems science are taught and learned in the context of the clinical science-focused clerkship year; to support students professional identity formation and wellness, and provide time for enrichment activities and scholarly work.

MDS 493.title: Independent Special Study Module
MDS 493.description: Student developed alternative to the SSM/SPO Requirement.  Approval by FYOC is required.

MDS 495.title: Medicine Literature Review
MDS 495.description: Independent study: topics for selection include, but are not restricted to, medical ethics, economics and jurisprudence, culture and medicine, ethnicity and medicine, gender and medicine, history of medicine, health manpower, and medical education. A prepared paper on the selected topic will be required.

MDS 499.title: Medical Student Research Fellowship
MDS 499.description: Independent research project as part of the Medical Student Research Fellowship.

MGB 203B.title: Forecasting & Managerial Research Methods
MGB 203B.description: Practical statistical methods for managerial decision making covers regression analysis, time series analysis and forecasting, design and analysis of experiments in managerial research and contingency table analysis. Application of these methods to marketing, finance, accounting, production, operations, and public policy.

MGB 269.title: Machine Learning with Python
MGB 269.description: Introduction to machine learning methods covering association rules, clustering, classification, and numeric prediction. Hands-on machine learning skills with Python. Big data technologies. Business applications.

MGB 292.title: Topics in Finance
MGB 292.description: Contemporary and emerging issues in finance. Application of modern techniques of finance to business problems. Use of appropriate electronic database and research techniques.

MGB 293.title: Topics in Marketing
MGB 293.description: Advanced topics in marketing, which may include marketing research, new product development, brand management, pricing, distribution management, service marketing, hitech marketing, advertising, sales promotions, marketing through the Web.

MGB 404Y.title: Marketing Management
MGB 404Y.description: Analysis of market opportunities, elements of market research, development of marketing strategies, market planning and implementations, and control systems. Consumer and industrial markets, market segmentation, pricing strategies, distribution channels, promotion, and sales.

MGB 405Y.title: Financial Theory & Policy
MGB 405Y.description: Corporate financial policy and investment management. Covers capital budgeting, optimal financial structure, cost-of-capital determination, risk measurement. Develops basic valuation principles for investments with long-lived and risky cash-flows, and extends these to derivative securities, asset portfolios, investment management and hedging.

MGB 423.title: Leader as Coach: An Introduction to Coaching Skills for Leaders
MGB 423.description: Introduces the fundamental coaching skills and coaching models that leaders can apply in everyday interactions with their team and colleagues in order to build trust, overcome challenges and help others discover their own full potential.

MGB 433.title: Corporate Social Responsibility
MGB 433.description: Learn practical information that will help students understand the basics of designing, managing and evaluating an effective CSR program. Expose students to a basic set of CSR issues in the context of cross-purpose business challenges and then focus on the analysis and critical decisions that managers must make to move their business and their social agenda forward.

MGB 435.title: Data Wrangling
MGB 435.description: Develop practical skills to pre-process data. Tidied raw data can then be used for downstream data analysis, modeling, and visualization.

MGB 460A.title: Corporate Finance: Fundamentals
MGB 460A.description: Course will study valuation techniques in applied settings, study a variety of investment decisions, and analyze how capital structure considerations play a role in firms investment policies.

MGB 460B.title: Corporate Finance: Advanced Topics
MGB 460B.description: Advanced course in corporate finance that builds on 460A, with an aim to extend knowledge of the theory and practice of corporate finance.

MGB 490.title: Topics in Business
MGB 490.description: Provides opportunity for students to gain experience in applying business methodologies previously acquired in other GSM courses.

MGB 490B.title: Topics in General Management-Extended
MGB 490B.description: Advanced topics in general management. Varied topics to cover more extensively issues discussed in the MBA core such business writing, management, organizational behavior, business communications, development, finance and workplace processes.

MGP 243.title: Customer Relationship Management
MGP 243.description: Customer Relationship Management (CRM) is a management approach under which marketing activities are organized and measured around customers (rather than around brands.) This approach is appealing because customers, not brands, are those who make buying decisions.

MGP 271.title: Strategic Cost Management
MGP 271.description: Theoretical frameworks and associated techniques for using organizational design and cost management to achieve a sustainable, profitable cost structure. Topics include: target costing, process design for low cost, total cost of ownership, cost of customers, implementing structural change, and incentives.

MGP 276.title: Real Estate, Finance & Development
MGP 276.description: Focus on single family, attached, detached, multi-family, and light commercial development. Study factors that make up successful real estate developments. Consider financial aspects involved in land acquisition, land development, construction, and project lending.

MGP 293.title: Topics in Marketing
MGP 293.description: Advanced topics in marketing, which may include marketing research, new product development, brand management, pricing, distribution management, service marketing, hitech marketing, advertising, sales promotions, marketing through the Web.

MGP 404Y.title: Marketing Management
MGP 404Y.description: Analysis of market opportunities, elements of market research, development of marketing strategies, market planning and implementations, and control systems. Consumer and industrial markets, market segmentation, pricing strategies, distribution channels, promotion, and sales.

MGP 405Y.title: Financial Theory & Policy
MGP 405Y.description: Corporate financial policy and investment management. Covers capital budgeting, optimal financial structure, cost-of-capital determination, risk measurement. Develops basic valuation principles for investments with long-lived and risky cash-flows, and extends these to derivative securities, asset portfolios, investment management and hedging.

MGP 423.title: Leader as Coach: An Introduction to Coaching Skills for Leaders
MGP 423.description: Introduces the fundamental coaching skills and coaching models that leaders can apply in everyday interactions with their team and colleagues in order to build trust, overcome challenges and help others discover their own full potential.

MGP 433.title: Corporate Social Responsibility
MGP 433.description: Learn practical information that will help students understand the basics of designing, managing and evaluating an effective CSR program. Expose students to a basic set of CSR issues in the context of cross-purpose business challenges and then focus on the analysis and critical decisions that managers must make to move their business and their social agenda forward.

MGP 435.title: Data Wrangling
MGP 435.description: Develop practical skills to pre-process data. Tidied raw data can then be used for downstream data analysis, modeling, and visualization.

MGP 436.title: Introduction to Derivative Securities
MGP 436.description: Introduction to derivative securities and other forms of financial innovations.

MGP 440.title: Integrated Management Project
MGP 440.description: Applies classroom learning to solve complex business challenges for real-world clients. Students learn practical consulting skills while their clients benefit from the students experience, insights, and work product.

MGP 460A.title: Corporate Finance: Fundamentals
MGP 460A.description: Study valuation techniques in applied settings, study a variety of investment decisions, and analyze how capital structure considerations play a role in firms investment policies.

MGP 460B.title: Corporate Finance: Advanced Topics
MGP 460B.description: Advanced course in corporate finance that builds on 460A, with an aim to extend knowledge of the theory and practice of corporate finance.

MGP 490.title: Topics in Business
MGP 490.description: Provides opportunity for students to gain experience in applying business methodologies previously acquired in other GSM courses.

MGP 492V.title: Topics in Finance
MGP 492V.description: Contemporary and emerging issues in finance. Application of modern techniques of finance to business problems. Use of appropriate electronic database and research techniques.

MGT 011A.title: Elementary Accounting
MGT 011A.description: Basic concepts of accounting; interpreting and using financial statements; understanding accounting principles.

MGT 011B.title: Elementary Accounting
MGT 011B.description: Theory of product costing; Analyzing the role and impact of accounting information on decision making; planning and performance evaluation.

MGT 012Y.title: Navigating Lifes Financial Decisions
MGT 012Y.description: Survey of major life financial decisions (e.g., career choice, consumption v. saving, investments, mortgages, insurance) and how decision-making biases (e.g., overconfidence, present bias, limited attention) can lead to suboptimal choice. Draws on research from economics, psychology, and sociology.

MGT 101.title: Sources & Uses of Accounting Information
MGT 101.description: Develops an understanding of the supply and demand of accounting information. Topics include the generation and processing of accounting information, the examination of accounting information by auditors, and the use of accounting information by capital markets and tax authorities.

MGT 103.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
MGT 103.description: Begin to develop expertise in the accounting for assets and introduce analysis of financial statements.

MGT 107.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting III
MGT 107.description: Finishes the Intermediate Financial Accounting series by examining in depth the accounting for contracts related to pensions and leases. Preparation of the statement of cash flows and footnote disclosures.

MGT 120.title: Managing and Using Information Technology
MGT 120.description: Develop an analytical framework to manage and monitor business systems concerned with operational, human, and organizational interactions. Introduction to computer hardware, systems software, and information systems. Management of information technology and the impact of information systems on modern management.

MGT 140.title: Marketing for the Technology-Based Enterprise
MGT 140.description: Quantitative analysis of needs in a product (technology-based) economy, with emphasis on how scientists, engineers, and business people interact to develop and market products and services.

MGT 150.title: Technology Management
MGT 150.description: Management of firms in high technology industries such as software development and biotechnology research. Motivating and managing workers, organizing for innovation, and making decisions.

MGT 151.title: Management of Innovation & Entrepreneurship
MGT 151.description: Innovation and entrepreneurship in established companies or new ventures. Knowledge, skills, and hands-on experiences in creative problem-solving, decision-making, building new ventures, and innovation strategy.

MGT 160.title: Financing New Business Ventures
MGT 160.description: Concepts/methods used to structure and finance new business ventures. Topics include evaluating the net social (financial) benefit of new investment projects; raising venture capital; the role of the venture capitalist; and the choice of organizational structure in new ventures.

MGT 170.title: Management Accounting & Control
MGT 170.description: Covers the design of cost accounting systems, the preparation of financial budgets and forecasts, cost analysis, and the use of cost and other financial data to motivate and evaluate the performance of business units and managers.

MGT 180.title: Supply Chain Planning & Management
MGT 180.description: Develops key concepts and relationships between supply chain design and business models and strategies. Much of the focus is on quantitative techniques for analysis & management of the production and delivery of goods & services by an organization.

MGT 198.title: Directed Group Study
MGT 198.description: Open to all undergraduates, but primarily intended for upper division students.

MGT 202B.title: Business, Government, & the International Economy
MGT 202B.description: Examines the influence of government and international factors on business. Topics include distribution of income, business cycles, inflation and interest rates, the federal debt, monetary policy and international trade and finance.

MGT 215.title: Business Law
MGT 215.description: Introduction to law and legal process in the United States. Sources of law. Structure and operation of courts, federal-state relationships, fundamentals of administrative law, fundamentals of business law.

MGT 234.title: Pricing
MGT 234.description: Combines lectures, cases and homework to teach students tools and skills necessary to analyze pricing situations, make pricing decisions, and implement them, in a systematic manner.

MGT 269.title: Machine Learning with Python
MGT 269.description: Introduction to machine learning methods covering association rules, clustering, classification, and numeric prediction. Hands-on machine learning skills with Python. Big data technologies. Business applications.

MGT 271.title: Strategic Cost Management
MGT 271.description: Theoretical frameworks and associated techniques for using organizational design and cost management to achieve a sustainable, profitable cost structure. Topics include: target costing, process design for low cost, total cost of ownership, cost of customers, implementing structural change, and incentives.

MGT 276.title: Real Estate, Finance & Development
MGT 276.description: Focus on single family, attached, detached, multi-family, and light commercial development. Students will study factors which make up successful real estate developments. Considers financial aspects involved in land acquisition, land development, construction, and project lending.

MGT 287.title: Business Database & Database Marketing
MGT 287.description: Practical introduction to fundamental principles of database management systems and database marketing. Database design. SQL queries. Concepts of database marketing, data warehouse, data visualization and big data analytics.

MGT 292.title: Topics in Finance
MGT 292.description: Contemporary and emerging issues in finance. Application of modern techniques of finance to business problems. Use of appropriate electronic database and research techniques.

MGT 423.title: Leader as Coach: An Introduction to Coaching Skills for Leaders
MGT 423.description: Introduces the fundamental coaching skills and coaching models that leaders can apply in everyday interactions with their team and colleagues in order to build trust, overcome challenges and help others discover their own full potential.

MGT 433.title: Corporate Social Responsibility
MGT 433.description: Learn practical information that will help students understand the basics of designing, managing and evaluating an effective CSR program. Expose students to a basic set of CSR issues in the context of cross-purpose business challenges and then focus on the analysis and critical decisions that managers must make to move their business and their social agenda forward.

MGT 436.title: Introduction to Derivative Securities
MGT 436.description: Introduction to derivative securities and other forms of financial innovations.

MGT 460A.title: Corporate Finance: Fundamentals
MGT 460A.description: Study valuation techniques in applied settings, study a variety of investment decisions, and analyze how capital structure considerations play a role in firms investment policies.

MGT 460B.title: Corporate Finance: Advanced Topics
MGT 460B.description: Advanced course in corporate finance that builds on 460A, with an aim to extend knowledge of the theory and practice of corporate finance.

MGT 490.title: Topics in Business
MGT 490.description: Provides opportunity for students to gain experience in applying business methodologies previously acquired in other GSM courses.

MGT 490B.title: Topics in General Management-Extended
MGT 490B.description: Advanced topics in general management. Varied topics to cover more extensively issues discussed in the MBA core such business writing, management, organizational behavior, business communications, development, finance and workplace processes.

MGV 200BV.title: Managerial Accounting
MGV 200BV.description: Information managers should know to be effective, including: product costing, motivating people, and differential analysis for decision making. Includes team projects and written and oral presentations.

MGV 201AV.title: The Individual & Group Dynamics
MGV 201AV.description: Examines basic psychological and social psychological processes shaping human behavior and applies knowledge of these processes to the following organizational problems: motivation, job design, commitment, socialization, culture, individual and group decision making, and team building.

MGV 201BV.title: Organizational Strategy & Structure
MGV 201BV.description: Strategic management of organizations, including analysis of industries, firm resources and capabilities and corporate strategy. Strategy formulation, implementation and strategic decision-making. Firm and industry life cycles and change.
